headline: In Soccer and Investing, Bias Is Toward Action
abstract: Carl Richards discusses the similarities between soccer goalkeepers and investors: both favor making some sort of move, when, in most cases, doing nothing at all would be the wiser decision.

abstract: Finding the right summer day camp, how to shield yourself from smartphone snoops, picking a name for a new dog and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: The Mattress Lot in Portland, Ore., makes deliveries by bicycle.

abstract: What to do if you inherit 700 dolls; a scientific, seven-minute workout; more errors in checks meant to aid homeowners and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Penney Enlists Blackstone to Help It Raise Money
abstract: J.C. Penney has hired the Blackstone Group to help it raise much-needed cash, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday, as the embattled retailer tries a turnaround after replacing its chief executive.

headline: A Tech M.&A. Machine Hits the Brakes
abstract: Nuance Communications, which has attracted Carl Icahn’s interest, has no shortage of well-defined operations like medical, enterprise and consumer that could be sold or spun off., the author writes.

headline: LivingSocial Hack Exposes Data for 50 Million Customers
abstract: Living Social told employees Friday that it had been hit by a cyberattack that may have left usernames, e-mail addresses, dates of birth and encrypted passwords for 50 million users vulnerable.

abstract: A grey egret in Guwahati, Assam.

headline: Google Introduces a Tool for Planning for Your Digital Afterlife
abstract: As Web companies and legislators grapple with who controls your digital life after you die, Google introduces a tool for designating what you want to happen to your data.

abstract: To understand the Chinese economy, it also helps to pay attention to changes in Chinese politics.

headline: Immigration and the Labor Market
abstract: By the accounts of many economic studies, an increase in immigration is likely to leave most American workers better off.

abstract: The accused refused to let the victim try to identify them in a magistrate’s court on Friday.

headline: Yoga Instructors, Tile Layers, Others Get New Outlet for Web Lessons
abstract: The founder of a new start-up, Curious, that begins on Wednesday believes he has created a better way for the little guys on YouTube and other video sites to teach others.

headline: 2 Deterrents to Robocalls Win F.T.C.’s Contest
abstract: The F.T.C. expressed hope that the winning proposals find their way to the marketplace soon to provide relief to millions of American consumers.

headline: Start-Up to Connect Home Appliances
abstract: Most makers of light switches, thermostats and other household appliances don’t have the expertise to build the Internet into their devices, nor can they afford adding a lot technology that significantly balloons the price of their products. Enter a start-up, Ayla Networks, which unveiled technology on Wednesday that it said would make bringing the Internet to ordinary devices more attractive for appliance makers.

headline: Google Isn’t Afraid of Building for Apple’s Turf
abstract: As the search giant adds to its portfolio of products meant for devices that run Apple’s iOS operating system, it also adds more ways to collect data about customers.

headline: A.I.G. Gives Chinese Buyers of Its Plane-Leasing Unit More Time
abstract: The American International Group says it has given a group of Chinese investors more time to complete a deal to buy its big airplane-leasing unit, nearly three weeks after the consortium missed a down payment.

headline: The S.E.C. Is ‘Bringin’ Sexy Back’ to Accounting Investigations
abstract: In the past, the Securities and Exchange Commission relied mainly on the market to flag accounting problems at companies that would lead to an investigation. Now, it is devising new programs to be more proactive.

headline: The Risks of America Doing Too Much in Syria
abstract: Richard N. Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations, the American foreign policy think tank, sat down with Rendezvous’s editor Marcus Mabry to talk Syria. Mr. Haass gave a long laundry list of what issues are more important to the United States than the bloodbath in Syria, even as he detailed the risks of that widening conflict.

headline: Singapore Censures 20 Banks Over Rates
abstract: Financial institutions, including Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, were found to have insufficient risk management and internal controls, which allowed some traders to try to alter rates.

headline: Q&A: Backing Up Photos in the Cloud
abstract: Those photos taken with your smartphone could be gone forever if you lose the phone or it breaks, but you can back them up online without having to physically sync with a computer.

headline: A Warning Shot on Management Buyouts
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s settlement with Revlon raises the question of whether the agency might start to police buyout offers from management and controlling shareholders that are rife with conflicts of interest.

headline: Looking at Facebook’s Friend and Relationship Status Through Big Data
abstract: Wolfram Alpha, a computational search engine, released a slew of fascinating data about Facebook users, including the age of friends, relationship status, and how these change based on age and geographical locations.

headline: Finding a High-Yield Checking Account
abstract: Some smaller banks offer high-yield checking accounts, but there are often catches.

headline: Razer’s Blade a Small, Powerful Gaming Laptop
abstract: Razer’s 14-inch Blade gaming computer, which at two-thirds of an inch, claims to be the thinnest available, delivers high performance graphics at a high price — $1,800 to $2,300, depending on the amount of memory.

headline: A Study That Set the Tone for Austerity Is Challenged
abstract: A 2010 paper argued that countries with heavy debt loads tended to experience slower rates of growth. A new study argues that the paper was flawed, in part because of calculation errors.

abstract: The May jobs report appears to show little change in the general economic picture, and for Wall Street that’s not a bad thing.

headline: Car-Sharing Service Suspended Over Insurance Concerns
abstract: RelayRides has stopped operating in New York after state authorities raised questions about its insurance coverage.

headline: Private Equity Firm Tied to New York Pension Scandal Raises $7.7 Billion From Investors
abstract: Riverstone Holdings, a leading private equity firm focused on energy and power, announced Wednesday that it had raised its largest-ever fund, a $7.7 billion vehicle that exceeds its $6 billion target.

headline: Suit Accuses Corzine of a Failure at the Helm
abstract: Federal regulators have announced a lawsuit against Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive of MF Global, in connection with the brokerage firm’s misuse of customer money during its final days.

abstract: Medical marijuana may pose risk for children, a new approach to sizing bras, federal program for distressed homeowners is extended and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: The battle for Dell has become a giant game of chicken between Carl Icahn and Michael Dell, one that is tilted against the company’s shareholders.

abstract: The billionaire Carl C. Icahn and Southeastern Asset Management, two of Dell’s biggest shareholders, seek to offer an alternative to a $24.4 billion takeover that they have criticized as “the great giveaway.”

headline: What the Oregon Health Study Can’t Tell
abstract: A landmark study of the health and care of Medicaid patients provides some striking findings, but the longer-term conclusions that can be drawn are limited.

abstract: The acquisition of Instagram by Facebook a year ago was risky, and Instagram is still not profitable. But the potential payout is increasing, the author contends.

abstract: An arbitration case shows the different choices financial firms make about where to house virtually identical assets and how those decisions can reduce costs.

headline: ID Theft Services Toning Down Some Claims
abstract: Identity-theft protection services are doing a better job of explaining what they do, and not promising more than they deliver, a consumer group says.

headline: An S.E.C. Settlement That Seems to Favor Falcone
abstract: Philip Falcone and his hedge fund are not acknowledging wrongdoing as part of a settlement with the S.E.C., and the agency is not even asking for an injunction against Mr. Falcone, the author writes.

headline: When Madison Avenue Went Public, as Seen on ‘Mad Men’
abstract: A back-of-the-envelope valuation of the fictional advertising agency Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, circa 1968, as DealBook takes a step into Don Draper’s world.

headline: A Vocabulary Site Shows How to Tailor Online Education
abstract: One of the educational potentials of computing is the ability to tailor learning experiences to the skills of individual students. A vocabulary-building site, Vocabulary.com, is an example of that potential, some educators say.

abstract: The Senate on Monday confirmed Mary Jo White to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission, dismissing concerns about her close ties to the Wall Street banks she will now oversee.

abstract: One in three bankers in London walked away empty handed from the last bonus round, a survey by the recruitment firm Morgan McKinley showed on Thursday.

abstract: In the last three months, the federal work force has shrunk by about 45,000 positions, including 14,000 in May alone.

abstract: The Blackstone Group’s sale of Vanguard Health Systems to a rival hospital chain, Tenet Healthcare, is the latest example of a successful cash-out.

abstract: Daniel K. Tarullo, a governor at the Federal Reserve, described a measure aimed at requiring the biggest banks to hold extra capital. Many might prefer to become smaller banks instead.

abstract: If debt investors are to shoulder the risk of suffering a loss, they will need more confidence about what lurks in banks’ balance sheets.

headline: Warm Welcome at Deutsche Bank Meeting, Followed by Rancor
abstract: The annual Deutsche Bank shareholders meeting began with applause for Anshu Jain, the bank’s co-chief executive, but attention quickly turned to the myriad problems that the bank has been trying to shake.

headline: Lloyds Chairman to Retire as Bank Landscape Shifts in Europe
abstract: Winfried Bischoff, the chairman of the Lloyds Banking Group and a former interim chief executive of Citigroup, will step down by May 2014, the latest departure among European banks.

headline: Do Small Businesses Understand the Customer Relationship Systems They Buy?
abstract: A consultant offers advice on picking the right system to manage customer relations.

headline: Google Close to Acquiring Waze, a Rival in Maps
abstract: The search giant, already a powerhouse in maps, is negotiating to buy the largely Israeli company for more than $1 billion, people familiar with the discussions say. Waze, which relies on GPS tracking and traffic reports from its users, would give Google more map data and better real-time traffic information.

headline: In China, Iron Man’s Muscle Is Fed by Inner Mongolian Milk
abstract: It’s not uncommon for China to ask for editing changes in movies to fit its ideological framework, but in the case of “Iron Man 3,” the movie actually added four minutes of product placements.

headline: Re-Re-engineering the Corporation
abstract: Asana, which sells social software for organizations, is introducing a version for companies with tens of thousands of employees. Eighteen months ago Asana catered to groups of 30. At a large scale, business social software may also enable another managerial revolution.

headline: A Tablet Stand That Is a Sound Improvement
abstract: The Definitive Technology Sound Cylinder clamps to a 7- or 10-inch tablet to improve sound quality.

headline: On Whether the Rich Pay Too Little in Taxes
abstract: A majority of Americans believe that high-income people do not pay enough in taxes, but that majority has been shrinking over the last couple of decades, according to new data from Gallup.

headline: As Business Lending Rises, Concerns Emerge About Profit
abstract: The recent spurt in bank business lending is starting to flash some warning signs. The concern is that banks are making loans to businesses at rates that are so low that they may end up being unprofitable for the lenders.

headline: J.W. Anderson and the Addictive Rush of Fashion
abstract: Suzy Menkes, the IHT’s fashion editor, talks to Jonathan (“J.W. Anderson”) Anderson at London Fashion Week about unisex styling, working with Donnatella Versace and the “addictive” rush of the industry today.

abstract: The largest commercial airline association called on a U.N. panel to adopt an across-the-board, market-based mechanism to offset carbon emissions.

abstract: The old stuff doesn’t work anymore. And that’s why I want to hire people who are trying to create new things.

abstract: Three of the five prosecution witnesses did not name Mr. Kumar until more than two decades after the 1984 riots, the 129-page judgment says.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include speculation about Sheryl Sandberg leaving Facebook and where she might go, a Web site that may have been one of the Facebook chief’s early efforts and investors giving Zynga a vote of confidence when it starts hosting online gambling in Britain.

headline: Fighting the Consultant Temptation
abstract: Is there ever a good reason for a fast-growth company to hire a consultant?

headline: The Case for Women
abstract: More power for women is inevitable, and a very good thing, an economist writes.

headline: Dimon’s Pyrrhic Victory
abstract: After beating back a shareholder plan to have a fully independent board, the bank faces more pressing concerns, like preventing similar trading losses and mending fences with regulators, the authors write.

abstract: Several Saudi Web sites came under attack this week by hackers claiming links with Anonymous, the loose hacking collective. The attacks follow a security researcher’s announcement that a Saudi company had asked him to help monitor citizens’ mobile communications.

abstract: Policies for the so-called middle class end up benefiting the rich at the expense of the poor, the author argues.

abstract: Flickr’s recent upgrade has discontinued the creation of new Flickr Pro accounts but adds three other options for free and paid photo sharing.

abstract: If you owe less than $50,000 in taxes but can’t pay then, you may qualify for an installment plan.

abstract: Kindoma Storytime, an iPad app, allows two people to read an e-book together, with both faces and the book appearing on each person’s screen.

abstract: Don’t let the rhetoric fool you, a Microsoft researcher says: Big Data is a human tool, which means it is subject to all kinds of miscollection, misapplication and abuse. While it is being promoted as a kind of data-driven truth, it is not and it poses a threat to privacy.

abstract: What have you given up for your start-up?

abstract: If you’re looking for a pattern in the stock market, you’re likely to find one. But investors would do better if they focused on their own behavioral patterns.

headline: Credit Suisse, Citing Large Profit, Says ‘Transformation’ All but Complete
abstract: Credit Suisse posted first-quarter earnings of $1.4 billion, a large increase from the period a year earlier when the bank booked large charges on its own debt.

abstract: Carl Richards asks investors to remember their feelings during the last stock market downturn so that they buy too many stock investments now, when the market is on the rise.

abstract: A beekeeper handling an artificial hive on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

abstract: Warren Buffett’s $5.6 billion bet on NV Energy in Nevada suggests he is coming up short on decent ways to deploy his cash.

abstract: The vague government mandate on tiger conservation has left much to interpretation.

headline: Dell Begins Campaign to Support Leveraged Buyout
abstract: Dell Inc. on Friday began its formal campaign to support a proposed $24.4 billion sale of the company to Michael S. Dell and the investment firm Silver Lake, amid continued opposition to the deal. The company set July 18 for the shareholder vote.

headline: Gang Rape Defendant Hopes to Join Indian Air Force
abstract: Air force rules disqualify anyone with criminal records from taking their selection test, but Vinay Sharma had applied before he was charged with participating in the gang rape of a 23-year-old woman.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Wednesday, selections include an effort to create new ways to market books using technology, utilities reporting widespread cyberattacks and a veteran technology analyst going to work for Apple.

abstract: The Blackstone Group told Dell that it would not even consider bidding unless Dell offered to pay the firm’s expenses, up to a whopping $25 million.

abstract: The Great Recession has been a disaster for the employment prospects of the young, but the story is quite different at the other end of the life cycle.

abstract: Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, took the unusual step on Monday of apologizing to Chinese customers over the company’s warranty policy and said he would improve customer service in the country, David Barboza and Nick Wingfield report in Tuesday’s New York Times.

abstract: The last of several Chinese bus drivers who were jailed and deported after striking in Singapore is back home; he says he has “no regrets” about the action, which shocked the tightly run city-state.

abstract: Prison authorities dismiss allegations of the defendant being beaten and poisoned in Tihar Jail.

headline: Daily Report: Dispute Over Tech Companies’ Motives in Immigration Debate

abstract: A report calls for the expansion of a recent experiment aimed at persuading highly qualified low-income students to apply to leading colleges.
